MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: The prisoner, unterrified, replied that he was Acetes of Mæonia; that

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: his parents, being poor, had left him their fisherman's trade, which

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: he had followed till he had acquired the pilot's art of steering his

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: course by the stars. It once happened that he had touched at the island

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: of Dia and had sent his men ashore for fresh water. They returned,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: bringing with them a lad of delicate appearance whom they had found

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: asleep. Judging him to be a noble youth, they thought to detain him

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: in the hope of liberal ransom. But Acetes suspected that some god was

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: concealed under the youth's exterior, and asked pardon for the violence

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: done. Whereupon the sailors, enraged by their lust of gain, exclaimed,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: "Spare thy prayers for us!" and, in spite of the resistance offered by

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Acetes, thrust the captive youth on board and set sail.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Then Bacchus (for the youth was indeed he), as if shaking off his

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: drowsiness, asked what the trouble was and whither they were carrying

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: him. One of the mariners replied, "Fear nothing; tell us where thou

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: wouldst go, and we will convey thee thither." "Naxos is my home," said

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Bacchus; "take me there, and ye shall be well rewarded." They promised

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: so to do; but, preventing the pilot from steering toward Naxos, they

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: bore away for Egypt, where they might sell the lad into slavery.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Soon the god looked out over the sea and said in a voice of weeping,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: "Sailors, these are not the shores ye promised me; yonder island is

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: not my home. It is small glory ye shall gain by cheating a poor boy."

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Acetes wept to hear him, but the crew laughed at both of them and sped

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: the vessel fast over the sea. All at once it stopped in mid-sea, as

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: fast as if it were fixed on the ground. The men, astonished, pulled at

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: their oars and spread more sail, but all in vain. Ivy twined round the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: oars and clung to the sails, with heavy clusters of berries. A vine

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: laden with grapes ran up the mast and along the sides of the vessel.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: The sound of flutes was heard, and the odor of fragrant wine spread all

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: around. The god himself had a chaplet of vine leaves and bore in his

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: hand a spear wreathed with ivy. Tigers crouched at his feet, and forms

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: of lynxes and spotted panthers played around him. The whole crew became

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: dolphins and swam about the ship. Of twenty men Acetes alone was left.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: "Fear not," said the god; "steer towards Naxos." The pilot obeyed, and

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: when they arrived there, kindled the altars and celebrated the sacred

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: rites of Bacchus.

line: So far had Acetes advanced in his narrative, when Pentheus,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: interrupting, ordered him off to his death. But from this fate the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: pilot, rendered invisible by his patron deity, was straightway rescued.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Meanwhile, the mountain Cithæron seemed alive with worshipers, and the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: cries of the Bacchanals resounded on every side. Pentheus, angered by

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: the noise, penetrated through the wood and reached an open space where

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: the chief scene of the orgies met his eyes. At the same moment the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: women saw him, among them his mother Agave, and Autonoë and Ino, her

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: sisters. Taking him for a wild boar, they rushed upon him and tore him

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: to pieces,--his mother shouting, "Victory! Victory! the glory is ours!"

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: So the worship of Bacchus was established in Greece.

MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: It was on the island of Naxos that Bacchus afterward found Ariadne, the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: daughter of Minos, king of Crete, who had been deserted by her lover,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Theseus. How Bacchus comforted her is related in another section. How

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: the god himself is worshiped is told by Edmund Gosse in the poem from

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH

line: Dancing to music, in their dance they fling

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH

line: Nearer they press, and nearer still in sight,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Still dancing blithely in a seemly choir;

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Tossing on high the symbol of their rite,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: The cone-tipped thyrsus of a god's desire;

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Nearer they come, tall damsels flushed and fair,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: With ivy circling their abundant hair;

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Onward, with even pace, in stately rows,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: With eye that flashes, and with cheek that glows,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: And all the while their tribute-songs they bring,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: And newer glories of the past disclose,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: And deathless praises to the vine-god sing.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: ... But oh! within the heart of this great flight,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Whose ivory arms hold up the golden lyre?

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: What form is this of more than mortal height?

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: What matchless beauty, what inspirèd ire!

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: The brindled panthers know the prize they bear,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: And harmonize their steps with stately care;

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Bent to the morning, like a living rose,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: The immortal splendor of his face he shows,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: And where he glances, leaf and flower and wing

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Tremble with rapture, stirred in their repose,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: And deathless praises to the vine-god sing....[148]

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: =113. The Choice of King Midas.=[149] Once Silenus, having wandered

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: from the company of Bacchus in an intoxicated condition, was found by

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: some peasants, who carried him to their king, Midas. Midas entertained

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: him royally and on the eleventh day restored him in safety to his

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: divine pupil. Whereupon Bacchus offered Midas his choice of a reward.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: The king asked that whatever he might touch should be changed into

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: gold. Bacchus consented. Midas hastened to put his new-acquired power

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: to the test. A twig of an oak, which he plucked from the branch, became

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: gold in his hand. He took up a stone; it changed to gold. He touched

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: a sod with the same result. He took an apple from the tree; you would

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: have thought he had robbed the garden of the Hesperides. He ordered

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: his servants, then, to set an excellent meal on the table. But, to his

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: dismay, when he touched bread, it hardened in his hand; when he put a

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: morsel to his lips, it defied his teeth. He took a glass of wine, but

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: it flowed down his throat like melted gold.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: He strove to divest himself of his power; he hated the gift he had

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: lately coveted. He raised his arms, all shining with gold, in prayer

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: to Bacchus, begging to be delivered from this glittering destruction.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: The merciful deity heard and sent him to wash away his fault and its

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: punishment in the fountainhead of the river Pactolus. Scarce had Midas

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: touched the waters, before the gold-creating power passed into them,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: and the river sands became golden, as they remain to this day.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: Thenceforth Midas, hating wealth and splendor, dwelt in the country and

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: became a worshiper of Pan, the god of the fields. But that he had not

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: gained common sense is shown by the decision that he delivered somewhat

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE GREAT DIVINITIES OF EARTH
line: later in favor of Pan's superiority, as a musician, over Apollo.[150]

line: =114. Myths of Ceres, Pluto, and Proserpine.= The search of Ceres for

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Proserpine, and of Orpheus for Eurydice, are stories pertaining both to

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Earth and Hades.

FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: =115. The Rape of Proserpine.=[151] When the giants were imprisoned

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: by Jupiter under Mount Ætna, Pluto (Hades) feared lest the shock of

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: their fall might expose his kingdom to the light of day. Under this

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: apprehension, he mounted his chariot drawn by black horses, and made a

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: circuit of inspection to satisfy himself of the extent of the damage.

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: While he was thus engaged, Venus, who was sitting on Mount Eryx playing

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: with her boy Cupid, espied him and said, "My son, take thy darts which

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: subdue all, even Jove himself, and send one into the breast of yonder

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: dark monarch, who rules the realm of Tartarus. Dost thou not see that

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: even in heaven some despise our power? Minerva and Diana defy us; and

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: there is that daughter of Ceres, goddess of earth, who threatens to

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: follow their example. Now, if thou regardest thine own interest or

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: mine, join these two in one." The boy selected his sharpest and truest

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: arrow, and sped it right to the heart of Pluto.

FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: companions, gathering lilies and violets, and singing, one may imagine,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: such words as our poet Shelley puts into her mouth:

FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Sacred Goddess, Mother Earth,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Thou from whose immortal bosom,

line: Gods, and men, and beasts, have birth,

line: Breathe thine influence most divine

line: If with mists of evening dew

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Till they grow, in scent and hue,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Fairest children of the hours,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Breathe thine influence most divine

FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Pluto saw her, loved her, and carried her off. She screamed for help to

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: her mother and her companions; but the ravisher urged on his steeds and

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: outdistanced pursuit. When he reached the river Cyane, it opposed his

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: passage, whereupon he struck the bank with his trident, and the earth

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: opened and gave him a passage to Tartarus.

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: =116. The Wanderings of Ceres.=[153] Ceres (Demeter) sought her

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: daughter all the world over. Bright-haired Aurora, when she came

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: forth in the morning, and Hesperus, when he led out the stars in the

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: evening, found her still busy in the search. At length, weary and

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: sad, she sat down upon a stone, and remained nine days and nights in

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: the open air, under the sunlight and moonlight and falling showers.

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: It was where now stands the city of Eleusis, near the home of an old

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: man named Celeus. His little girl, pitying the old woman, said to

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: her, "Mother,"--and the name was sweet to the ears of Ceres,--"why

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: sittest thou here alone upon the rocks?" The old man begged her to

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: come into his cottage. She declined. He urged her. "Go in peace," she

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: replied, "and be happy in thy daughter; I have lost mine." But their

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: compassion finally prevailed. Ceres rose from the stone and went with

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: them. As they walked, Celeus said that his only son lay sick of a

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: fever. The goddess stooped and gathered some poppies. Then, entering

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: the cottage, where all was in distress,--for the boy Triptolemus

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: seemed past recovery,--she restored the child to life and health with

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: a kiss. In grateful happiness the family spread the table and put upon

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: it curds and cream, apples, and honey in the comb. While they ate,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Ceres mingled poppy juice in the milk of the boy. When night came, she

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: arose and, taking the sleeping boy, molded his limbs with her hands,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: and uttered over him three times a solemn charm, then went and laid

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: him in the ashes. His mother, who had been watching what her guest

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: was doing, sprang forward with a cry and snatched the child from the

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: fire. Then Ceres assumed her own form, and a divine splendor shone

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: all around. While they were overcome with astonishment, she said,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: "Mother, thou hast been cruel in thy fondness; for I would have made

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: thy son immortal. Nevertheless, he shall be great and useful. He shall

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: teach men the use of the plow and the rewards which labor can win from

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: the soil." So saying, she wrapped a cloud about her and mounting her

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: chariot rode away.

FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Ceres continued her search for her daughter till at length she returned

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: to Sicily, whence she first had set out, and stood by the banks of the

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: river Cyane. The river nymph would have told the goddess all she had

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: witnessed, but dared not, for fear of Pluto; so she ventured merely

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: to take up the girdle which Proserpine had dropped in her flight, and

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: float it to the feet of the mother. Ceres, seeing this, laid her curse

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: on the innocent earth in which her daughter had disappeared. Then

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: succeeded drought and famine, flood and plague, until, at last, the

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: fountain Arethusa made intercession for the land. For she had seen that

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: it opened only unwillingly to the might of Pluto; and she had also, in

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: her flight from Alpheüs through the lower regions of the earth, beheld

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: the missing Proserpine. She said that the daughter of Ceres seemed sad,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: but no longer showed alarm in her countenance. Her look was such as

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: became a queen,--the queen of Erebus; the powerful bride of the monarch

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: of the realms of the dead.

FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: When Ceres heard this, she stood awhile like one stupefied; then she

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: implored Jupiter to interfere to procure the restitution of her

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: daughter. Jupiter consented on condition that Proserpine should not

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: during her stay in the lower world have taken any food; otherwise, the

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Fates forbade her release. Accordingly, Mercury was sent, accompanied

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: by Spring, to demand Proserpine of Pluto. The wily monarch consented;

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: but alas! the maiden had taken a pomegranate which Pluto offered her,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: and had sucked the sweet pulp from a few of the seeds. A compromise,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: however, was effected by which she was to pass half the time with her

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: mother, and the rest with the lord of Hades.

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD

line: By yonder cypresses on that soft rise,

line: Breathe slow, O heart, breathe slow!

line: A presence from below

line: Moves toward the breathing world from that dark deep,

line: Whereof men fabling tell what no man knows,

line: By little fires amid the winter snows,

line: O Proserpine, dream not that thou art gone

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Far from our loves, half-human, half-divine;

line: Thou hast a holier adoration won

line: Where light and warmth behold me,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: He who so loved thee that the live earth clove

line: =117. Triptolemus and the Eleusinian Mysteries.= Ceres, pacified with

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: this arrangement, restored the earth to her favor. Now she remembered,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: also, Celeus and his family, and her promise to his infant son

line: Triptolemus. She taught the boy the use of the plow and how to sow the

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: seed. She took him in her chariot, drawn by winged dragons, through

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: all the countries of the earth; and under her guidance he imparted to

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: return Triptolemus built a temple to Ceres in Eleusis and established

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: the worship of the goddess under the name of the Eleusinian mysteries,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: which in the splendor and solemnity of their observance surpassed all

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: other religious celebrations among the Greeks.

line: =118. Orpheus and= =Eurydice.=[155] Of mortals who have visited Hades

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: and returned, none has a sweeter or sadder history than Orpheus, son of

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Apollo and the Muse Calliope. Presented by his father with a lyre and

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: taught to play upon it, he became the most famous of musicians, and not

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: only his fellow mortals but even the wild beasts were softened by his

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: strains. The very trees and rocks were sensible to the charm. And so

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: also was Eurydice,--whom he loved and won.

FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Hymen was called to bless with his presence the nuptials of Orpheus

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: with Eurydice, but he conveyed no happy omens with him. His torch

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: smoked and brought tears into the eyes. In keeping with such sad

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: prognostics, Eurydice, shortly after her marriage, was seen by the

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: shepherd Aristæus, who was struck with her beauty and made advances

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: to her. As she fled she trod upon a snake in the grass, and was bitten

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: in the foot. She died. Orpheus sang his grief to all who breathed the

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: upper air, both gods and men, and finding his complaint of no avail,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: resolved to seek his wife in the regions of the dead. He descended by

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: a cave situated on the side of the promontory of Tænarus, and arrived

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: in the Stygian realm. He passed through crowds of ghosts and presented

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: himself before the throne of Pluto and Proserpine. Accompanying his

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: words with the lyre, he sang his petition for his wife. Without her

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: he would not return. In such tender strains he sang that the very

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: ghosts shed tears. Tantalus, in spite of his thirst, stopped for a

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: moment his efforts for water, Ixion's wheel stood still, the vulture

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: ceased to tear the giant's liver, the daughters of Danaüs rested

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: from their task of drawing water in a sieve, and Sisyphus sat on his

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: rock to listen.[156] Then for the first time, it is said, the cheeks

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: of the Furies were wet with tears. Proserpine could not resist and

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Pluto himself gave way. Eurydice was called. She came from among

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: the new-arrived ghosts, limping with her wounded foot. Orpheus was

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: permitted to take her away with him on condition that he should not

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: turn round to look at her till they should have reached the upper air.

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: Under this condition they proceeded on their way, he leading, she

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: following. Mindful of his promise, without let or hindrance the bard

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: passed through the horrors of hell. All Hades held its breath.

line: "Ah, what!" she cried, "what madness hath undone

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD

FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: The Thracian maidens tried their best to captivate him, but he repulsed

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: their advances. Finally, excited by the rites of Bacchus, one of them

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: exclaimed, "See yonder our despiser!" and threw at him her javelin. The

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: weapon, as soon as it came within the sound of his lyre, fell harmless

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: at his feet; so also the stones that they threw at him. But the women,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: raising a scream, drowned the voice of the music, and overwhelmed him

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: with their missiles. Like maniacs they tore him limb from limb; then

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: cast his head and lyre into the river Hebrus, down which they floated,

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: murmuring sad music to which the shores responded. The Muses buried the

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: fragments of his body at Libethra, where the nightingale is said to

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: sing over his grave more sweetly than in any other part of Greece. His

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: lyre was placed by Jupiter among the stars; but the shade of the bard

Poem Title: FROM THE EARTH TO THE UNDERWORLD
line: passed a second time to Tartarus and rejoined Eurydice.

MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: =119. Lord of the Sea.= Neptune (Poseidon) was lord both of salt

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: waters and of fresh. The myths that turn on his life as lord of the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: sea illustrate his defiant invasions of lands belonging to other gods,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: or his character as earth shaker and earth protector. Of his contests

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: with other gods, that with Minerva for Athens has been related. He

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: contested Corinth with Helios, Argos with Juno, Ægina with Jove, Naxos

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: with Bacchus, and Delphi with Apollo. That he did not always make

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: encroachments in person upon the land that he desired to possess or

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: to punish, but sent some monster instead, will be seen in the myth of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: Andromeda[159] and in the following story of Hesione,[160] the daughter

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: of Laomedon of Troy.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: Neptune and Apollo had fallen under the displeasure of Jupiter after

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: the overthrow of the giants. They were compelled, it is said, to

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: resign for a season their respective functions and to serve Laomedon,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: then about to build the city of Troy. They aided the king in erecting

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: the walls of the city but were refused the wages agreed upon. Justly

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: offended, Neptune ravaged the land by floods and sent against it a sea

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: monster, to satiate the appetite of which the desperate Laomedon was

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: driven to offer his daughter Hesione. But Hercules appeared upon the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: scene, killed the monster, and rescued the maiden. Neptune, however,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: nursed his wrath; and it was still warm when the Greeks marched against

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
line: Troy.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS

line: by mortal mothers. From him were sprung the savage Læstrygonians,

line: Orion, the Cyclops Polyphemus, the giant Antæus whom Hercules slew,

line: Procrustes, and many another redoubtable being whose fortunes are

Poem Title: MYTHS OF NEPTUNE, RULER OF THE WATERS

MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF HEAVEN
line: [Illustration: FIG. 97. PHOSPHOR, EOS, AND HELIOS (THE SUN) RISING FROM
THE SEA]
=123. Cephalus and Procris.=[163] Aurora, the goddess of the dawn, fell
in love with Cephalus, a young huntsman. She stole him away, lavished
her love upon him, tried to content him, but in vain. He cared for his
young wife Procris more than for the goddess. Finally, Aurora dismissed
him in displeasure, saying, "Go, ungrateful mortal, keep thy wife; but
thou shalt one day be sorry that thou didst ever see her again."
Cephalus returned and was as happy as before in his wife. She, being
a favorite of Diana, had received from her for the chase a dog and a
javelin, which she handed over to her husband. Of the dog it is told
that when about to catch the swiftest fox in the country, he was
changed with his victim into stone. For the heavenly powers, who had
made both and rejoiced in the speed of both, were not willing that
either should conquer. The javelin was destined to a sad office. It
appears that Cephalus, when weary of the chase, was wont to stretch
himself in a certain shady nook to enjoy the breeze. Sometimes he would
say aloud, "Come, gentle Aura, sweet goddess of the breeze, come and
allay the heat that burns me." Some one, foolishly believing that he
addressed a maiden, told the secret to Procris. Hoping against hope,
she stole out after him the next morning and concealed herself in the
place which the informer had indicated. Cephalus, when tired with
sport, stretched himself on the green bank and summoned fair Aura as
usual. Suddenly he heard, or thought he heard, a sound as of a sob in
the bushes. Supposing it to proceed from some wild animal, he threw his
javelin at the spot. A cry told him that the weapon had too surely met
its mark. He rushed to the place and raised his wounded Procris from
the earth. She, at last, opened her feeble eyes and forced herself to
utter these words: "I implore thee, if thou hast ever loved me, if I
have ever deserved kindness at thy hands, my husband, grant me this
last request; marry not that odious Breeze!" So saying, she expired in
her lover's arms.
[Illustration: FIG. 98. SUN, RISING, PRECEDED BY DAWN
From the painting by Guido Reni]
[Illustration: FIG. 99. SUNRISE; EOS PURSUING CEPHALUS]
=124. Dobson's The Death of= =Procris.= A different version of the
story is given in the following:
Procris, the nymph, had wedded Cephalus;--
He, till the spring had warmed to slow-winged days
Heavy with June, untired and amorous,
Named her his love; but now, in unknown ways,
His heart was gone; and evermore his gaze
Turned from her own, and even farther ranged
His woodland war; while she, in dull amaze,
Beholding with the hours her husband changed,
Sighed for his lost caress, by some hard god estranged.
So, on a day, she rose and found him not.
Alone, with wet, sad eye, she watched the shade
Brighten below a soft-rayed sun that shot
Arrows of light through all the deep-leaved glade;
Then, with weak hands, she knotted up the braid
Of her brown hair, and o'er her shoulders cast
Her crimson weed; with faltering fingers made
Her golden girdle's clasp to join, and past
Down to the trackless wood, full pale and overcast.
And all day long her slight spear devious flew,
And harmless swerved her arrows from their aim,
For ever, as the ivory bow she drew,
Before her ran the still unwounded game.
Then, at the last, a hunter's cry there came,
And, lo! a hart that panted with the chase.
Thereat her cheek was lightened as with flame,
And swift she gat her to a leafy place,
Thinking, "I yet may chance unseen to see his face."
Leaping he went, this hunter Cephalus,
Bent in his hand his cornel bow he bare,
Supple he was, round-limbed and vigorous,
Fleet as his dogs, a lean Laconian pair.
He, when he spied the brown of Procris' hair
Move in the covert, deeming that apart
Some fawn lay hidden, loosed an arrow there;
Nor cared to turn and seek the speeded dart,
Bounding above the fern, fast following up the hart.
But Procris lay among the white wind-flowers,
Shot in the throat. From out the little wound
The slow blood drained, as drops in autumn showers
Drip from the leaves upon the sodden ground.
None saw her die but Lelaps, the swift hound,
That watched her dumbly with a wistful fear,
Till, at the dawn, the hornèd wood-men found
And bore her gently on a sylvan bier,
To lie beside the sea,--with many an uncouth tear.
=125. Ceyx and Halcyone.= The son of Aurora and Cephalus was Phosphor,
the Star of Morning. His son Ceyx, king of Trachis in Thessaly, had
married Halcyone, daughter of Æolus.[164] Their reign was happy until
the brother of Ceyx met his death. The direful prodigies that followed
this event made Ceyx feel that the gods were hostile to him. He thought
best therefore to make a voyage to Claros in Ionia to consult the
oracle of Apollo. In spite of his wife's entreaties (for as daughter
of the god of winds she knew how dreadful a thing a storm at sea was),
Ceyx set sail. He was shipwrecked and drowned. His last prayer was that
the waves might bear his body to the sight of Halcyone, and that it
might receive burial at her hands.
In the meanwhile, Halcyone counted the days till her husband's promised
return. To all the gods she offered frequent incense, but more than all
to Juno. The goddess, at last, could not bear to be further pleaded
with for one already dead. Calling Iris, she enjoined her to approach
the drowsy dwelling of Somnus and bid him send a vision to Halcyone in
the form of Ceyx, to reveal the sad event.
[Illustration: FIG. 100. THE GOD OF SLEEP]
Iris puts on her robe of many colors, and tinging the sky with her
bow, seeks the cave near the Cimmerian country, which is the abode of
the dull god, Somnus. Here Ph[oe]bus dare not come. Clouds and shadows
are exhaled from the ground, and the light glimmers faintly. The cock
never there calls aloud to Aurora, nor watchdog nor goose disturbs the
silence. No wild beast, nor cattle, nor branch moved with the wind,
nor sound of human conversation breaks the stillness. From the bottom
of the rock the river Lethe flows, and by its murmur invites to sleep.
Poppies grow before the door of the cave, from whose juices Night
distills slumbers which she scatters over the darkened earth. There
is no gate to creak on its hinges, nor any watchman. In the midst, on
a couch of black ebony adorned with black plumes and black curtains
the god reclines, his limbs relaxed in sleep. Around him lie dreams,
resembling all various forms, as many as the harvest bears stalks, or
the forest leaves, or the seashore sand grains.
Brushing away the dreams that hovered around her, Iris lit up the cave
and delivered her message to the god, who, scarce opening his eyes, had
great difficulty in shaking himself free from himself.
Then Iris hasted away from the drowsiness creeping over her, and
returned by her bow as she had come. But Somnus called one of his
sons, Morpheus, the most expert in counterfeiting forms of men, to
perform the command of Iris; then laid his head on his pillow and
yielded himself again to grateful repose.
Morpheus flew on silent wings to the Hæmonian city, where he assumed
the form of Ceyx. Pale like a dead man, naked and dripping, he stood
before the couch of the wretched wife and told her that the winds of
the Ægean had sunk his ship, that he was dead.
Weeping and groaning, Halcyone sprang from sleep and, with the dawn,
hastening to the seashore, descried an indistinct object washed to and
fro by the waves. As it floated nearer she recognized the body of her
husband. In despair, leaping from the mole, she was changed instantly
to a bird, and poured forth a song of grief as she flew. By the mercy
of the gods Ceyx was likewise transformed. For seven days before and
seven days after the winter solstice, Jove forbids the winds to blow.
Then Halcyone broods over her nest; then the way is safe to seafarers.
Æolus confines the winds that his grandchildren may have peace.
=126. Aurora and Tithonus.=[165] Aurora seems frequently to have been
inspired with the love of mortals. Her greatest favorite, and almost
her latest, was Tithonus, son of Laomedon, king of Troy. She stole him
away and prevailed on Jupiter to grant him immortality; but forgetting
to have youth joined in the gift, after some time she began to discern,
to her great mortification, that he was growing old. When his hair was
white she left his society; but he still had the range of her palace,
lived on ambrosial food, and was clad in celestial raiment. In time
he lost the power of using his limbs; and then she shut him up in his
chamber, whence his feeble voice might at times be heard. Finally, she
turned him into a grasshopper.
=127. Tennyson's Tithonus.= The following is, according to a fine
poetic conception, the lament of the old man when but a white-haired
shadow:
The woods decay, the woods decay and fall,
The vapors weep their burthen to the ground,
Man comes and tills the field and lies beneath,
And after many a summer dies the swan.
Me only cruel immortality
Consumes: I wither slowly in thine arms,
Here at the quiet limit of the world,
A white-haired shadow roaming like a dream
The ever silent spaces of the East,
Far-folded mists, and gleaming halls of morn.
Alas! for this gray shadow, once a man--
So glorious in his beauty and thy choice,
Who madest him thy chosen, that he seem'd
To his great heart none other than a God!
I ask'd thee, "Give me immortality."
Then didst thou grant mine asking with a smile,
Like wealthy men who care not how they give;
But thy strong Hours indignant work'd their wills,
And beat me down and marr'd and wasted me,
And tho' they could not end me, left me maim'd
To dwell in presence of immortal youth,
Immortal age beside immortal youth,
And all I was, in ashes. Can thy love,
Thy beauty, make amends, tho' even now,
Close over us, the silver star, thy guide,
Shines in those tremulous eyes that fill with tears
To hear me? Let me go: take back thy gift:
Why should a man desire in any way
To vary from the kindly race of men,
Or pass beyond the goal of ordinance
Where all should pause, as is most meet for all?
A soft air fans the cloud apart; there comes
A glimpse of that dark world where I was born.
Once more the old mysterious glimmer steals
From thy pure brows, and from thy shoulders pure,
And bosom beating with a heart renew'd.
Thy cheek begins to redden thro' the gloom,
Thy sweet eyes brighten slowly close to mine,
Ere yet they blind the stars, and the wild team
Which love thee, yearning for thy yoke, arise,
And shake the darkness from their loosen'd manes,
And beat the twilight into flakes of fire.
Lo! ever thus thou growest beautiful
In silence, then before thine answer given
Departest, and thy tears are on my cheek.
Why wilt them ever scare me with thy tears,
And make me tremble lest a saying learnt
In days far-off, on that dark earth, be true?
"The gods themselves cannot recall their gifts."
Ay me! ay me! with what another heart
In days far-off, and with what other eyes
I used to watch--if I be he that watched--
The lucid outline forming round thee; saw
The dim curls kindle into sunny rings;
Changed with thy mystic change, and felt my blood
Glow with the glow that slowly crimson'd all
Thy presence and thy portals, while I lay,
Mouth, forehead, eyelids, growing dewy-warm
With kisses balmier than half-opening buds
Of April, and could hear the lips that kiss'd
Whispering I knew not what of wild and sweet,
Like that strange song I heard Apollo sing,
While Ilion like a mist rose into towers.
Yet hold me not forever in thine East:
How can my nature longer mix with thine?
Coldly thy rosy shadows bathe me, cold
Are all thy lights, and cold my wrinkled feet
Upon thy glimmering thresholds, when the steam
Floats up from those dim fields about the homes
Of happy men that have the power to die,
And grassy barrows of the happier dead.
Release me, and restore me to the ground;
Thou seëst all things, thou wilt see my grave:
Thou wilt renew thy beauty morn by morn;
I earth in earth forget these empty courts,
And thee returning on thy silver wheels.
=128. Memnon=, the son of Aurora and Tithonus, was king of the
Æthiopians. He went with warriors to assist his kindred in the Trojan
War, and was received by King Priam with honor. He fought bravely, slew
Antilochus, the brave son of Nestor, and held the Greeks at bay until
Achilles appeared. Before that hero he fell.
Then Aurora, seeing her son's fate, directed his brothers, the Winds,
to convey his body to the banks of the river Æsepus in Mysia. In the
evening Aurora, accompanied by the Hours and the Pleiads, bewept her
son. Night spread the heaven with clouds; all nature mourned for the
offspring of the Dawn. The Æthiopians raised his tomb on the banks
of the stream in the grove of the Nymphs, and Jupiter caused the
sparks and cinders of his funeral pile to be turned into birds, which,
dividing into two flocks, fought over the pile till they fell into the
flame. Every year at the anniversary of his death they celebrated his
obsequies in like manner. Aurora remained inconsolable. The dewdrops
are her tears.[166]
[Illustration: FIG. 101. THE DEATH OF MEMNON]
The kinship of Memnon to the Dawn is certified even after his death. On
the banks of the Nile are two colossal statues, one of which is called
Memnon's; and it was said that when the first rays of morning fell
upon this statue, a sound like the snapping of a harp-string issued
therefrom.[167]
So to the sacred Sun in Memnon's fane
Spontaneous concords choired the matin strain;
Touched by his orient beam responsive rings
The living lyre and vibrates all its strings;
Accordant aisles the tender tones prolong,
And holy echoes swell the adoring song.[168]

Pyth. 6, 30.
[168] Darwin, Botanic Garden.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: plowman, now as vinedresser, now as apple-picker, now as fisherman, now

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: admired her fruit, admired especially the luxuriance of her grapes,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.

line: had hanged himself to her gatepost; and how the gods had turned the

line: =140. The Cranes of Ibycus=.[182] The Furies, called also Diræ (the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: terrible ones), Erinyes (the persecutors, or the angered ones), and

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: finally, by way of euphemism, Eumenides (the well-meaning), though

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: they were spirits of the underworld, visited earth to punish filial

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: disobedience, irreverence to old age, perjury, murder, treachery to

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: guests, even unkindness toward beggars. They avenged the ghosts of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: such as, dying violent deaths, possessed on earth no representatives

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: either by law or by kindred to avenge them. Therefore, as we shall see,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: they persecuted Orestes, who had slain his mother. Therefore, like

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: the accusing voice of conscience, they marshaled to punishment the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: murderers of Ibycus.

line: Soon afterward, the vast assemblage in the amphitheater sat listening

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: to a play in which the Chorus personated the Furies. The Choristers,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: clad in black, bore in their fleshless hands torches blazing with a

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: pitchy flame. Advancing with measured step, they formed ranks in the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: orchestra. Their cheeks were bloodless, and in place of hair writhing

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: serpents curled around their brows. Forming a circle, these awful

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: beings sang their hymn. High it swelled, overpowering the sound of the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.

MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: "Happy the man whose heart is pure from guilt and crime! Him we

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: avengers touch not; he treads the path of life secure from us. But woe!

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: woe! to him who has done the deed of secret murder. We, the fearful

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: brood of Night, fasten ourselves upon him, soul and flesh. Thinks he by

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: flight to escape us? Fly we still faster in pursuit, twine our snakes

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: around his feet, and bring him to the ground. Unwearied we pursue; no

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: pity checks our course; still on, still on to the end of life, we give

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: no peace, no rest."

line: Stillness like the stillness of death sat over the assembly. Suddenly

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: a cry burst from one of the uppermost benches,--"Lo, comrade, the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: avengers of Ibycus!" A flock of cranes crossed the sky. "The murderer

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: has informed against himself," shouted the assemblage. The inference

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: was correct. The criminals, straightway seized, confessed the crime and

Poem Title: MYTHS OF THE LESSER DIVINITIES OF EARTH, ETC.
line: suffered the penalty.

the root _p[)a]_, to feed, to pasture (i.e. the flocks and herds).

line: For the first time in his life the Cyclops began to care for his

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: appearance; he harrowed his coarse locks with a currycomb, mowed his

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: beard with a sickle, and, looking into the sea when it was calm,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: count beauty,--and the sea reflects the gleam of my teeth whiter than

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: the Parian stone."[183]

line: ... He loved, not with apples, not roses, nor locks of hair,

line: but with fatal frenzy; and all things else he held but trifles

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: by the way. Many a time from the green pastures would his ewes

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: stray back, self-shepherded, to the fold. But he was singing

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: of Galatea; and pining in his place, he sat by the seaweed of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: the beach from the dawn of day with the direst hurt beneath his

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: breast of mighty Cypris' sending,--the wound of her arrow in his

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: heart!

line: Yet this remedy he found, and sitting on the crest of the tall

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: cliff and looking to the deep, 'twas thus he would sing:

MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: "Oh, milk-white Galatea, why cast off him that loves thee? More

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: white than is pressed milk to look upon, more delicate than the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: lamb art thou, than the young calf wantoner, more sleek than

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: the unripened grape! Here dost thou resort, even so, when sweet

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: sleep possesses me, and home straightway dost thou depart when

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: sweet sleep lets me go, fleeing me like an ewe that has seen the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: gray wolf. I fell in love with thee, maiden, I, on the day when

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: first thou camest, with my mother, and didst wish to pluck the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: hyacinths from the hill, and I was thy guide on the way. But to

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: leave loving thee when once I had seen thee, neither afterward,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: nor now at all, have I the strength, even from that hour. But to

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: thee all this is as nothing, by Zeus, nay, nothing at all!

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: "I know, thou gracious maiden, why it is that thou dost shun me.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: It is all for the shaggy brow that spans my forehead, from this

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: to the other ear, one long, unbroken eyebrow. And but one eye is

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: on my forehead, and broad is the nose that overhangs my lip. Yet

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: I (even such as thou seest me) feed a thousand cattle, and from

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: these I draw and drink the best milk in the world. And cheese I

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: never lack, in summer time or autumn, nay, nor in the dead of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: winter, but my baskets are always overladen.

MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: "Also I am skilled in piping, as none other of the Cyclopes here,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: and of thee, my love, my sweet apple, and of myself, too, I sing,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: many a time, deep in the night. And for thee I tend eleven fawns,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: all crescent browed, and four young whelps of the bear. Nay, come

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: thou to me and thou shalt lack nothing that now thou hast....

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: "But if thou dost refuse because my body seems shaggy and rough,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: well, I have faggots of oak-wood, and beneath the ashes is fire

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: unwearied, and I would endure to let thee burn my very soul, and

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: this my one eye, the dearest thing that is mine.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: "Ah me, that my mother bore me not a finny thing, so would I have

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: gone down to thee, and kissed thy hand, if thy lips thou would

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: not suffer me to kiss! And I would have brought thee either white

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: lilies or the soft poppy with its scarlet petals. Nay, these are

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: summer's flowers, and those are flowers of winter, so I could not

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: have brought thee them all at one time.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: "Now, verily, maiden, now and here will I learn to swim, if

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: perchance some stranger come hither, sailing with his ship, that

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: I may see why it is so dear to thee to have thy dwelling in the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: deep. Come forth, Galatea, and forget as thou comest, even as I

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: that sit here have forgotten, the homeward way!...

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: "Oh, Cyclops, Cyclops, whither are thy wits wandering? Ah, that

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: thou wouldst go and weave thy wickerwork and gather broken boughs

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: to carry to thy lambs: in faith, if thou didst this, far wiser

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: wouldst thou be!

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: "Milk the ewe that thou hast; why pursue the thing that shuns

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: thee? Thou wilt find, perchance, another, and a fairer, Galatea.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Many be the girls that bid me stay with them, and softly they all

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: laugh, if perchance I answer them. On land it is plain that I,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: too, seem to be somebody!"[184]

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Having, one day, in such wise sung, Polyphemus wandered, beside

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: himself for passion, into the woods. On a sudden he came in sight of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Galatea and Acis in the hollow of a rock, where they had hearkened to

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: the strains of the Cyclops. The monster, infuriate, crying that this

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: should be the last of their love-meetings, overwhelmed his rival with a

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: tremendous rock. Purple blood spirted from under the stone, by degrees

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: grew paler, and finally became the stream that still bears the name of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: the unfortunate youth. But Galatea remained inconsolable.[185]

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: [Illustration: FIG. 113. A SEA-GOD]

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: =142. Glaucus and Scylla.=[186] Another deity of the sea was Glaucus,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: the son of that Sisyphus who was punished in Hades for his treachery

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: to the gods. Glaucus had been a comely young fisherman; but having

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: noticed that a certain herb revived fishes after they were brought to

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: land, he ate of it and suffered metamorphosis into something new and

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: strange, half man, half fish, and after the fashion of a sea-god. Of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: his experience during this "sea change" the following is an account:

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: I plunged for life or death. To interknit

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: One's senses with so dense a breathing stuff

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Might seem a work of pain; so not enough

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Can I admire how crystal-smooth it felt,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: And buoyant round my limbs. At first I dwelt

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Whole days and days in sheer astonishment;

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Forgetful utterly of self-intent,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Moving but with the mighty ebb and flow.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Then like a new-fledged bird that first doth show

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: His spreaded feathers to the morrow chill,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: I tried in fear the pinions of my will.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: 'Twas freedom! and at once I visited

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: The ceaseless wonders of this ocean bed.[187]

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: He became guardian of fishes and divers and of those who go down to

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: the sea in ships. Later, being infatuated of the fair virgin Scylla

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: (daughter of the sea-god Phorcys and granddaughter of Pontus), he

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: paid his court to her, but the maiden rejected him. Whereupon, in

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: desperation, Glaucus sought the aid of Circe, an enchantress. She,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: because she coveted for herself the handsome sea-green god, transformed

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: her rival into a monster hideously fashioned of serpents and barking

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: dogs.[188] In this shape Scylla thereafter infested the shore of Sicily

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: and worked evil to mariners,[189] till finally she was petrified as a

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: reef, none the less perilous to all seafarers.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: A modern version of the fate of Glaucus and Scylla is given by Keats in

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: the Endymion. Glaucus consents to Circe's blandishments for a season,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: but becoming disgusted with her treachery and cruelty, he endeavors

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: to escape from her. The attempt proving unsuccessful, he is brought

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: back and sentenced to pass a thousand years in decrepitude and pain.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Consequently, returning to the sea, he there discovers the body of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Scylla, whom the goddess has not transformed, but drowned, and learns

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: that if he passes his thousand years in collecting the bodies of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: drowned lovers, a youth beloved of the gods will, in time, appear and

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: help him. This prophecy is fulfilled by Endymion, who aids in restoring

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Glaucus to youth, and Scylla and the drowned lovers to life.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: =143. Nisus and Scylla.=[190] The daughter of Phorcys is frequently

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: confounded with another Scylla, daughter of King Nisus of Megara.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Scylla of Megara betrayed her father to his enemy, Minos II of Crete,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: with whom, although the kings were at war, she had fallen violently in

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: love. It seems that Nisus had on his head a purple lock of hair, upon

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: which depended his fortune and his life. This lock his daughter clipped

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: and conveyed to Minos. But recoiling from the treacherous gift, that

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: king, after he had conquered Megara, bound Scylla to the rudder of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: his ship and so dragged her through the waves toward Crete. The girl

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: was ultimately transformed into the monster of the barking dogs, or,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: according to another authority, into a bird continually the prey of the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: sea eagle, whose form her father Nisus had assumed.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: =144. Leucothea.=[191] Another sea change was that of Ino, the daughter

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: of Cadmus and wife of Athamas, who, flying from her frantic husband,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: sprang, with her child Melicertes in her arms, from a cliff into the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: sea. The gods, out of compassion, made her a goddess of the sea under

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: the name of Leucothea, and her son a god under that of Palæmon. Both

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: were held powerful to save from shipwreck and were invoked by sailors.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Palæmon was usually represented as riding on a dolphin. In his honor

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: the Isthmian games were celebrated. By the Romans he was called

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Portumnus, and had jurisdiction of ports and shores.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: =145. Proteus and Aristæus.=[192] Though Aristæus, the lover of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Eurydice, was son of Apollo and guardian himself of herds and flocks,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: protector of vine and olive, and keeper of bees, still he was son of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Cyrene, a water-nymph, and his most interesting adventure brought him

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: into contact with another deity of the sea.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: His bees having perished, Aristæus resorted for aid to his mother. She,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: surrounded by her maidens in the crystalline abode under her river,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: overheard his complaints and ordered that he should be brought into her

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: presence. The stream at her command opened itself and let him enter,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: while it stood heaped like a mountain on either side. Cyrene and her

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: nymphs, having poured out libations to Neptune, gave the youth to eat

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: and listened to his complaint, then informed him that an aged prophet

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: named Proteus, who dwelt in the sea and pastured the sea calves of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Neptune, could explain the cause of the mortality among the bees and

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: how to remedy it; but that the wizard would have to be chained and

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: compelled to answer, and that even when chained, he would try to escape

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: by assuming a series of dreadful forms. "Still, thou hast but to keep

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: him fast bound," concluded Cyrene, "and at last, when he finds his

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: arts of no avail, he will obey thy behest." The nymph then sprinkled

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: her son with nectar, whereupon an unusual vigor filled his frame and

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: courage his heart.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Cyrene led her son to the prophet's cave, which was in the island of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Pharos, or of Carpathos,[193] and concealed him. At noon issued Proteus

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: from the water, followed by his herd of sea calves, which spread

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: themselves along the shore. He, too, stretched himself on the floor of

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: the cave and went to sleep. Aristæus immediately clapped fetters on him

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: and shouted at the top of his voice. Proteus, finding himself captured,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: resorted to his craft, becoming first a fire, then a flood, then a

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: horrible wild beast, in rapid succession; nor did he succumb till all

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: schemes had failed to set him free. Then he resumed his old form and,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: in response to the questioning of Aristæus, said: "Thou receivest the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: merited reward of thy deed, by which Eurydice met her death. To avenge

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: her, the nymphs have sent this destruction on thy bees. Their anger

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: thou must appease. Four bulls shalt thou select, of perfect form and

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: size, and four cows of equal beauty; and four altars shalt thou build

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: to the nymphs, and shalt sacrifice the animals, leaving their carcasses

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: in the leafy grove. To Orpheus and Eurydice thou shalt pay such funeral

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: honors as may allay their resentment. Returning after nine days,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: examine the bodies of the cattle slain and see what has befallen."

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Aristæus faithfully obeyed these directions. Returning to the grove on

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: the ninth day he found that a swarm of bees had taken possession of one

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: of the carcasses and were pursuing their labors there as in a hive.[194]

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: =146. Acheloüs and Hercules.=[195] A similar contest took place

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: between Hercules and the river-god Acheloüs. The cause of the strife

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: was Dejanira of Calydon, whom both heroes loved. Hercules boasted his

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: divine descent. Acheloüs, not content with advancing his claim as

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: lord of the mightiest and most ancient river of Greece, insinuated

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: suspicions with regard to the value of Hercules' pretensions. Then

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: began a mighty struggle. Finding he was no match for Hercules in

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: the wrestler's art, Acheloüs glided away in the form of a serpent.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Hercules, remarking that it was the labor of his infancy to strangle

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: snakes,[196] clasped the neck of Acheloüs and choked him. Then

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Acheloüs assumed the seeming of a bull. Whereupon Hercules, seizing

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: him by the horns, dragged his head to the ground, overthrew him, and

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: rent one horn away. This trophy the Naiads consecrated and filled with

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: flowers for the goddess of Plenty, who, adopting it as her symbol,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: named it Cornucopia.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: [Illustration: FIG. 114. NEREÏDS AND SEA MONSTERS]

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: =147. Milton's Sabrina Fair.= No writer in modern times has made more

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: graceful poetic use of the divinities of the streams than has Milton.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: The following song, chanted by a Spirit in invocation of "the gentle

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: nymph" (of the poet's invention) "that with moist curb sways the smooth

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Severn stream," is but one refrain of many caught by the poet from the

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: far-echoing chorus of classical verse:

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Sabrina fair,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Listen where thou art sitting

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Under the glassy, cool, translucent wave,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: In twisted braids of lilies knitting

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: The loose train of thy amber-dropping hair;

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Listen for dear honor's sake,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Goddess of the silver lake,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Listen and save.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Listen and appear to us

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: In name of great Oceanus.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: By th' earth-shaking Neptune's mace,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: And Tethys' grave, majestic pace,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: By hoary Nereus' wrinkled look,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: And the Carpathian wizard's hook,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: By scaly Triton's winding shell,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: And old soothsaying Glaucus' spell,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: By Leucothea's lovely hands,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: And her son that rules the strands,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: By Thetis' tinsel-slippered feet,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: And the songs of Sirens sweet,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: By dead Parthenope's[1] dear tomb

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: And fair Ligea's[197] golden comb,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Wherewith she sits on diamond rocks,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Sleeking her soft, alluring locks,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: By all the nymphs that nightly dance

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Upon thy streams with wily glance;

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Rise, rise, and heave thy rosy head

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: From thy coral-paven bed,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: And bridle in thy headlong wave,

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Till thou our summons answered have.

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
line: Listen and save.[198]

Poem Title: MYTHS OF LESSER DIVINITIES OF THE WATERS
